/simply-edit/.meta title: Simply edit the web - by ylebre
/simply-edit/.project-tagline: Use the key 'demo' to try out Simply edit.
/simply-edit/.main-content:
Simply edit GitHub Pages

This page was automatically generated using GitHub Pages and modified to add support for Simply edit. This editor uses the markup provided in the HTML to merge the page with the data, clientside. In this example, the page data is also stored in GitHub.

Not just Markdown

While Markdown is fine for most uses, this editor allows you to fully leverage the power of HTML. By using <template> instructions within the HTML, the editor can insert any HTML structure you want. Modifications on the page are quick and simple, leaving you in control. Take a peek at the quick integration guide for more information, or check out the Sublime template or the Spectral template.

Plays well with others

This editor was designed with an expanding web in mind. The toolbars in the pages are context-aware and are easily added to the editor to add specific options for specific HTML structures. The basic version supports the most commonly used HTML elements (text, images, hyperlinks), but more toolbars are available. Each editor context uses CSS-like selectors to decide which toolbar is best suited. Read more about adding toolbars and adding editable field types.

CMS Integrations

We are looking for developers that want to help us integrate Simply edit into various platforms. We have integrated the editor in Ariadne, our own web application platform, but the world of the web is a much larger place. Since the editor is now totally decoupled from Ariadne, we want to share it with as many users as possible. Read more about CMS integration.

Support or Contact

Having trouble with the editor? Have an idea for a 'must have' plugin? Drop me a line here on GitHub.

             Simply-edit is maintained by ylebre.        This page was generated by GitHub Pages using the Cayman theme by Jason Long.

meta description.content: Quick integration guide for Simply edit

/simply-edit/integration.html.project-tagline: How to deploy Simply edit on your site
/simply-edit/integration.html.main-content:
How to deploy the editor on your site

Here is a quick integration guide to add Simply edit to your own website. You will need some experience with HTML for this, although we tried really hard to make this as simple as possible.

Lets say you have a heading in your page. The HTML will look something like this:

<h1>This is my title</h1>

We need to give the editor a hint that this should be editable, and what the contents are, like so: 

<h1 data-simply-field="title">This is my title</h1>

Repeat this for all the elements you want to make editable.

Include the editor javascript just before the </body> tag:

<script src="http://se-cdn.muze.nl/simply-edit.js" data-api-key="github"></script>

Repeating elements and templates

In most HTML templates you will encounter repeating elements, for instance a menu or a list of blog posts. There elements all share the same HTML structure. For example:

<ul class="posts">
  <li class="post">
    <h3>The title of the post</h3>
    <p>This is the description</p>
  </li>
</ul>

We want to tell the editor that we have a lists of posts, and that each post within the list should have the same HTML structure. Each list item has an editable title and description:

<ul class="posts" data-simply-list="posts">
  <template data-simply-template="Post">
    <li class="post">
      <h3 data-simply-field="title">The title of the post</h3>
      <p data-simply-field="description">This is the description</p>
    </li>
  </template>
</ul>

Simply edit vocabulary

data-simply-field=name

This is editable.

data-simply-path=/simply-edit/

Store the data within a specific path. This allows you to have fields that have the same contents across pages. 

data-simply-type=text

Applies to fields. This field contains plain text (no HTML). 

data-simply-list=name

This is a list, data for the list entries will be stored as 'name' 

data-simply-template=name

Applies on <template> tags, used to provide a list with an HTML template for list entries

data-simply-sortable

Applies to lists, makes it sortable

data-simply-selectable

Tells the editor that this element is selectable as a unit data-simply-list-item Tells the editor that this element is an entry in a list

data-simply-hidden

Tells the editor that this element should be hidden with display:none when in editmode. Use to remove pesky hovering elements that go over editable text.

/simply-edit/adding-toolbars.html.project-tagline: How to add custom toolbars to the editor
/simply-edit/adding-toolbars.html.main-content:
Extending Simply edit

With the speed the web is evolving, it is neigh impossible to keep up with the development pace. With this in mind Simply edit was designed so that its parts are easily replaced and new functions are easily added. Simply edit decides what toolbar to show based on a context - this is basicly what the user has selected on the screen. The editor finds out what context it is in using context filters, which are usually configured along with the rest of a toolbar.

Context filters are a lot like CSS selectors, except they are bottom up. The deeper the context is found, the more weight it carries.

Here is an example of a context filter:
editor.addContextFilter(
  "simply-hyperlink", {
     "selector" : "A",
     "parent" : { "selector" : "*" },
     "context" : "simply-text-selection
});

This filter applies for any hyperlink (A tag), with any parent selector. So when a user clicks on any hyperlink in the page, the context 'simply-text-selection' is selected and that toolbar is shown. Here is a full example of a toolbar, including the javascript to add it to the editor.

<section id="simply-text-cursor" class="simply-section">
   <div class="simply-toolbar">
      <ul class="simply-buttons">
         <li><button data-simply-section="simply-text-style" class="simply-expands">
            <i class="fa fa-magic"></i>Style</button></li>
         <li><button data-simply-section="simply-text-align" class="simply-expands">
            <i class="fa fa-align-left"></i>Align</button></li>
      </ul>
      <div class="simply-toolbar-section simply-text-style">
         <ul>
            <li class="simply-text-bold"><button data-simply-action="simply-text-bold">
               <i class="fa fa-bold"></i>Bold</button></li>
         </ul>
      </div>
   </div>
</section>

<script>
   editor.addToolbar({
       "name" : "simply-text-cursor",
       "filter" : { "sel-collapsed" : true },
        update : updateTextToolbar,
        init : function(toolbar) { }
   });
<script>

Here is a breakdown of what is happening:

<section id="simply-text-cursor" class="simply-section">

The name of this toolbar is 'simply-text-cursor';

<div class="simply-toolbar">
Where the toolbar buttons go

<ul class="simply-buttons">
Display a horizontal list of buttons

<li><button data-simply-section="simply-text-style" class="simply-expands">
     <i class="fa fa-magic"></i>Style</button></li>

Show a button with a magic wand icon, with the text 'style'. This button gets the class 'simply expand' (which adds a little arrow on the bottom of the button). The attribute 'data-simply-section' points to which toolbar section is shown when this button is expanded.

<div class="simply-toolbar-section simply-text-style">
Add a toolbar section (which expands when the corresponding button is activated); This section gets the class 'simply-text-style', corresponding to the data-simply-section on the button that expands it.

<ul>
Display a list of buttons

<li class="simply-text-bold"><button data-simply-action="simply-text-bold">
    <i class="fa fa-bold"></i>Bold</button></li>
Show a button with a 'bold' icon and the text 'style'. When the button is clicked, invoke the editor action 'simply-text-bold';

editor.addToolbar({
// Add a toolbar for the context 'simply-text-cursor' (required)
   "name" : "simply-text-cursor",
// Show this toolbar when the selection is collapsed; (required)
   "filter" : { "sel-collapsed" : true },
// Each time the toolbar is shown, run this function. Add code to update button states and such here. (optional)
   update : function(toolbar) { },
// When the toolbar is first loaded, run this code to initialize everyhing. (optional)
   init : function(toolbar) { },
// Add these actions to the editor. Note that these actions are globally available, so you can override specific actions in the editor this way. (optional)
   actions : { 'simply-text-bold' : function(button) { }
// Run the code to make the current selection bold;
});              

Simply-edit is maintained by ylebre.        This page was generated by GitHub Pages using the Cayman theme by Jason Long.

/simply-edit/cms-integrations.html.meta title: Simply edit the web - by ylebre
/simply-edit/cms-integrations.html.main-content:
Welcome to GitHub Pages.

This automatic page generator is the easiest way to create beautiful pages for all of your projects. Author your page content here using GitHub Flavored Markdown, select a template crafted by a designer, and publish. After your page is generated, you can check out the new gh-pages branch locally. If you’re using GitHub Desktop, simply sync your repository and you’ll see the new branch.

Designer Templates

We’ve crafted some handsome templates for you to use. Go ahead and click 'Continue to layouts' to browse through them. You can easily go back to edit your page before publishing. After publishing your page, you can revisit the page generator and switch to another theme. Your Page content will be preserved.

Creating pages manually

If you prefer to not use the automatic generator, push a branch named gh-pages to your repository to create a page manually. In addition to supporting regular HTML content, GitHub Pages support Jekyll, a simple, blog aware static site generator. Jekyll makes it easy to create site-wide headers and footers without having to copy them across every page. It also offers intelligent blog support and other advanced templating features.

Authors and Contributors

You can @mention a GitHub username to generate a link to their profile. The resulting <a> element will link to the contributor’s GitHub Profile. For example: In 2007, Chris Wanstrath (@defunkt), PJ Hyett (@pjhyett), and Tom Preston-Werner (@mojombo) founded GitHub.

Support or Contact

Having trouble with Pages? Check out our documentation or contact support and we’ll help you sort it out.

             Simply-edit is maintained by ylebre.        This page was generated by GitHub Pages using the Cayman theme by Jason Long.

/simply-edit/cms-integration.html.project-tagline: Adding a custom storage layer to Simply Edit
/simply-edit/cms-integration.html.main-content:
Adding a custom storage layer

Simply Edit allows you to add your own storage layer. This layer is responsible for storing and retrieving the JSON data blob, as well as listing files and images for the browse dialogs.

To add a custom storage layer, create a storage object before loading simply-edit.js. Pass the variable name of the object to Simply Edit with the attribute data-simply-storage:

<script src="http://se-cdn.muze.nl/simply-edit.js"
data-api-key="github"
data-simply-storage="mycustomStorage">

Here is a skeleton for the storage layer so you can roll your own:

var myCustomStorage = {
 init : function(endpoint) {
  /**
   Initialization for the storage layer
   endpoint: (string) URL location for the backend endpoint.
  */
 
  /* Do things to initialize your storage layer. */
 
  /*Save the endpoint for later use. */
  this.endpoint = endpoint;
 },
 save : function(data, callback) {
  /**
   Saves data in the backend
   data: (string) contains the new JSON blob with site data.
   callback: (function) the function to call after the save is done.
  */
 },
 load : function(callback) {
  /**
   Load data from the backend.
   callback: (function) the function to call after the data is loaded. The JSON blob with site data will be passed as its only argument.
  */
 },
 connect : function() {
  /**
   This function is called before editmode is started and before a save operation is called.
   Add checks to validate the credentials here.
  */
 },
 disconnect : function() {
  /**
   Disconnect from the backend storage, remove credentials.
  */
 },
 list : function(url, callback) {
  /**
   List files, folders and images for the given endpoint URL;
   
   This function is called with 'endpoint/data.json' to populate the sitemap dialog.
   I suggest adding special handling for JSON blob file to return the contents of the blob.
   
   This function is used by the sitemap, image browse and file browse dialogs.
   
   url: (string) url to list the images from.
   callback: (function) callback function to call with the list.
   
   Example list:
   {
    folders : [
     {
      url : "http://endpoint.com/folder1/",
      name : "Folder 1"
     },
     {
      url : "http://endpoint.com/folder2/",
      name : "Folder 1"
     }
    ],
    files : [
     {url : "http://endpoint.com/myfile.txt"},
     {url : "http://endpoint.com/myfile2.txt"},
     {url : "http://endpoint.com/myfile3.txt"},
     {url : "http://endpoint.com/image1.png"},
     {url : "http://endpoint.com/image2.png"}
    ],
    images : [
     {url : "http://endpoint.com/image1.png"},
     {url : "http://endpoint.com/image2.png"}
    ]
   }
  */
 },
 
 /**
  Optional functions, only add these if you need them.
 */
 checkJail : function(url) {
  /**
   Check if the given URL is part of our site.
   This function is used when navigating to a page that is not in our data blob (yet).
   
   Returns true if the url should be stored in the data blob.
   Returns false otherwise.
  */
 },
 saveTemplate : function(template, callback) {
  /**
   Copy a page template file to the current URL location, used for adding new pages.
   template: (string) name of the chosen template file to copy;
   callback (function) callback function to call after the copy has been made.
  */
 }
};

/simply-edit/adding-field-types.html.meta title: Simply edit the web - by ylebre
